noCardsLeftMessage.title: There are no longer any questions in your area for the moment.
noCardsLeftMessage.text:
‚ú®  Enjoying the premium offer to deactivate your geolocation and quell with questions from around the world  ‚ú®

No, it's fun.
Finally, it says, maybe you should turn off your geolocation if you want to save battery. And at the same time, you do well what you want with your phone. And then it's practical, GPS, anyway. I remember this time I had to go to visit my aunt L√©onie in the Perche, and ... Anyway.

safeSpace.title: Let's get the impostor syndrome together.
safeSpace.description:
A junior developer, you are suffering from the impostor syndrome?

At Electronic Tales, we believe that this is not inevitable.

ancientWorld.title: Ancient World
ancientWorld.description: Immerses in the world engulfed in computer science.
ancientWorld.alert: Come on. Did you expect what? The Nine Circles of Hell? The design department didn't have enough budget for that.

why.title: Why  ?
why.body:
Thanks to the explosion of short formations, more and more storefronts come from different backgrounds, and it is so much better.

However, once in business, these people sometimes feel that a "glass wall" separates them from their older colleagues from more traditional routes. A wall built on cultural or technical references that they do not have  üññ ü•ö üöÄ ‚ùìüöÄüöÄ

Add to this the development-specific complexity (program is hard, the technos evolve very quickly, it is impossible to know ...), and all the ingredients are combined to develop a good well-typed impostor syndrome.

body.text:
Imprest syndrome is a very common problem for developers.

The problem is that you rarely dare to talk about it  üò∂


Or, discussing it with other devs is an essential first step:
body.list:
• Be aware that you are not alone in galore  üö£üèº
  • Technically progress on healthier bases  üí™
  • Teach together a movement of detox  üå± üçµ from a sometimes toxic environment  ü§¢ ‚ò¢Ô∏è

microExperiences.description:
Florilege of everyday situations that you should never live in the world of the dev.

You have a micro-lived experience to share? Do not hesitate, we will publish it anonymously or under a pseudonym.

microExperience.label: You have a micro-lived to share? We will be delighted to read it and publish it.

ourChat.title: Our Slack
ourChat.descriptionAfterLink: To allow the devs to talk to the open heart of the problems that they can live in tech.

rules.intro: For the well-being of all, we ask you to follow two main principles:
rules.list:
• üòé  Uses a Pseudo

    Let us leave aside real names, workplaces and business names-find the swag of theInternet at the beginning of the 2000s and liberate the word.

  • ü§ó  N ' never forgets inclusion and respect

    No racism, validism, sexism, homophobia, transphobia, body shaming and any other -   isms, -   ing , and -   phobias Likely to make someone uncomfortable. It requires a lot of energy and courage to speak, even anonymously in a remote corner of the Internet, so we will be intransigent on the issue.
